headline.main: STUDY OF WAYS TO REDUCE HEART ATTACK RISK IS PROVING OUT

docs.lead_paragraph: Middle-aged men participating in a major national study have succeeded in changing their habits to reduce their risk of suffering a heart attack, according to a series of newly published reports on the study's progress. Although it will be two more years before it is known whether the changes will, in fact, result in fewer heart attacks, the researchers expressed ''cautious optimism'' about the study's potential to demonstrate the combined life-saving effects of lowering blood cholesterol and blood pressure and of stopping smoking among men who fa ce a high risk of heart disea se. In smaller studies, independent changes in each of the factors have reduced the chances of premature death from cardiovascular disease. The $98 million study, referred to as ''MR FIT'' (for Multiple Risk Factor Intervention Trial), is sponsored by the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. The largest project of its kind, it involves 12,866 initially healthy men being studied at 22 medical centers around the country.

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The President of Brazil, Joao Baptista Figueiredo, suffered a heart attack here yesterday. His chief aide announced tonight that Vice President Aureliano Chaves would soon assume the presidency temporarily. Mr. Cha ves would be the first civilian to l ead Brazil since 1964, when a military coup brought into office the first of five successivemilitary heads of state. Joao Leitao de Abreu, the presidential adviser who disclosed the decision in a press conference tonight, said that doctors attending Mr. Figueiredo had decided that he would require eight weeks of recuperation before he could resume his duties.

headline.main: SENATE DEFEATS MOVE TO END SUGAR SUBSIDIES

byline.original: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The old coalition of farm state senators regrouped today as the Senate rejected a consumer-backed amendment that would have prohibited price supports for sugar. After that vote, the Senate defeated by a vote of 53 to 42 an amendment to eliminate Federal support for tobacco fa rmers as it continued work on the Agriculture Committee's comprehensive four-yearfarm bill. The bill includes a proposal that would have the effect of guaranteeing American farmers at least 18 cents a pound for their sugar. The current free market price for sugar is about 15 cents a pound.
